question_content.barrons:question: The author’s attitude toward the experiment involving the captive fat mouse can best be described as one of
question_content.barrons:explanation:
scientific detachment.

The author describes the experiment’s results ("A captive fat mouse was once kept without food or water for thirty-six days; at the end of that time it had lost a third of its weight but appeared quite healthy.") both clearly and unemotionally. His attitude is one of scientific detachment or objectivity.

Righteous indignation is incorrect. The author is not indignant or annoyed about the way the mouse has been treated.

Skeptical disbelief is incorrect. The author is not skeptical or incredulous about the way the mouse has been treated

Grudging admiration is incorrect. While the author may well admire the experiment he cites, nothing in the passage suggest that his admiration is grudging or reluctant.

Marked disapprobation is incorrect. Nothing in the passage suggests that the author disapproves of the experiment. His attitude is not one of marked disapprobation.
